dialogues.text: Today seems like it will be a hot day.
Yes. It might rain.
Yes, it has rained quite a bit, these past few weeks.
Well, I'm off for my malaria education community visits.
Adwoa, do you have everything?

text: Hey, Adwoa, let's check if you have everything you need.

info_start: Adwoa, your bag will contain the things you may need on your rounds.
Select 9 items into your bag.
Let's GO!
info_end: You've got off to a great start with your community visit.
You chose all the right things you might need making sure it focused on the objective of Malaria education.
We think you're going to really help your clients on this community visit.
info_skip: You will lose some points for this
info_replay: Sorry Adwoa.
Unfortunately not all the items you selected might be needed on this community visit.
Remember, the objective is Malaria education!
Focus on that and pick the right items.
Let's give this another try.

pages.text: Adwoa, your bag will contain the things you may need on your rounds. Select 9 items into your bag.

text:
Excellent Adwoa!

You've got off to a great start with your community visit. You chose all the right things you might need making sure it focused on the objective of Malaria education.

We think you're going to really help your clients on this community visit.

Sorry Adwoa.

Unfortunately not all the items you selected might be needed on this community visit. Remember, the objective is Malaria education, so focus on that and pick the right items.

Let's give this another try.

Adwoa, now that you've got items in your bag, let's learn how to use them.
 
Click the BAG ICON on the bottom right to activate your Nurses toolkit.
To use an item from your toolkit, click on it. Let's test this. Click the 'Hello Nurse' item.

dialogues.text: Yes, I have everything I need
Okay. See you soon
Almost there.

pages.text: Who should Adwoa check on first?

dialogues.text:
Do I have a choice? Knowing Agya Atakora, 
he will be annoyed if I don't check on him first

Aunty Aku is usually nicer to deal 
with than Agya Atakora. Hope she's around today.

Great! A compound meeting.
This gives me an opportunity to talk to them 
as a group. I've been meaning to talk about...
Good Morning
Good Morning.
...Morning...

I am happy to see you all already gathered together.
 I have something important to say.
As I was entering, I looked around. A nice house like this, and it has a leaky roof. That's not right.
For all you know, it means the roof is weak. I think the whole thing needs changing...
...Asem ben koraa nie. Aunty Nurse. Why? Are you saying I am an irresponsible landlord?
Agya Atakora. I just...
...Stop! This is not your business. Does a roof need injection? Aunty Nurse, please leave my compound. Now!

text:
Sorry! Yes, your job includes looking out for health and 
safety hazards and a leaky roof may be one such dangers

However being a good judge of how to deliver health advice and what the most important 
advice is in context, is a skill you must acquire for the field.
Sorry! You missed out the most important things to do as a nurse in this situation.

You may have won some people over but you failed to achieve your primary mission.
Don't forget that this community visit had the specific objective of malaria education.
Being Miss Popular was most definitely not the objective!

dialogues.text: Good Morning
Good Morning.
...Morning...
How are you all? It's good to see you all gathered here.
Eh, Efia why?  Your dressing... As a nurse I must give advice on all health related issues.
Hmmm... Aunty Nurse say it.
Efia. Did you buy the wrong size of clothes? Should I come and donate some of mine to you?
Aunty Nurse. Some of us are dying.
Please. Leave me alone...
Doesn't she know the boys in this area are bad. She has to be careful.
Aunty Nurse. Come and see something for me.
Ok..
Good Morning
Good Morning.
...Morning...
How are you all? I am happy to see you all already gathered together
Yes we were discussing some issues.
Good. As I was coming in, I looked around and noticed rain puddles all around.
It's been raining off and on for 2 weeks. This means mosquito larvae may have already began forming in these puddles. You have to be more careful.

text:
Hey, Adwoa, let's remind these people about how mosquitoes cause malaria. 

A. Let's get out the Malaria Flashcards. 
B. Select the Malaria Flashcards and let's teach the household about malaria.
Your bag contains things you may need on your rounds. Use items in your bag as required
Good Job Nurse!

dialogues.text: Thank you all for listening.
Thank You
...Thank You...
Aunty Nurse. Come and see something for me.
Sure. With permission from Agya Atakora, of course
Aunty Nurse. You are very respectful. You have my permission.
Come in...
So Aunty Nurse. What do you see?
Wow, Aunty Aku. You've bought curtains and eh, a fan too. Business must be booming.
Nyame Adom nkoa.
Tell me all about it...
15mins later...
Wow! I am impressed. Aunty Aku, I have to leave now but I will be back for more business tips.
Adwoa, my favorite nurse. You can come at any time.

text: Yes, you won the heart of Aunty Aku but you got so caught up in her life you forget completely you were there to perform a task
Being friendly is a good attitude towards patients and community members but not to the detriment of forgetting to help keep them free of malaria

dialogues.text: So Aunty Nurse. What do you see?
Hmm... Aunty Aku. Do you really want me to say it?
Yes...
Aunty Aku, you have dirty utensils inside your room? That's not how a proper hardworking woman behaves.
Eh. Adwoa? You're saying I'm lazy. You're lucky you're a nurse. You'd have seen my true colours today.
Hmm Me I came to advice you and if you wont listen fine.
Adowa, leave. I won't let you talk to me like a child. Leave oooo, leave!!

text: Ouch! You missed out the most important things to do as a nurse in this situation and rather became, Madam Okro Mouth.
Pointing out  things which affect cleanliness is part of your job, but this community visit had a specific objective, malaria education.

dialogues.text: So Aunty Nurse. What do you see?
Aunty Aku, I see a bed without a mosquito net. Where did your bed net go?
Oh, Aunty Nurse, you didn't see my new curtains? As for the net, I have a fan so I don't need it.
Aunty Aku, your curtains are nice, but please continue to use the net to be sure of full protection.
Insecticide Treated Nets (ITNs) kill the mosquitoes, unlike a fan which just blows them away.
Aunty Nurse, you always correct me when I am wrong. Thank you, as always.
You're welcome. See you next time.
Agya Atakora and his tenants have really used up my time
As for Ama, she's so obedient and follows instructions very well.  I shouldn't be long there.
Nurse Adwoa. Welcome ooo. I have been expecting you
Yes Ama. Thank You. I'm later than usual. How are you my darling?
Fine by God's Grace.
Ama can I see your Maternal Health Record Book, the ANC booklet?
Yes, Nurse Adwoa. I have it ready for you to inspect.
Adwoa, you really want the best for your child I can see.
Yes
Did you sleep in your net last night?
Yes. But can you believe I managed to get it torn up badly this morning
Can you help me fix it up?
Yes, I can.
Ama, you know something. I'm running late. So far you've been obedient.
Yes, Nurse.
So if there's nothing special, I would like to leave you. Keep visiting the ANC clinic and you will be fine

text: No! Ama may have done the right things in the past and should be commended but don't assume patients will continue to do the right.
Don't Rush! As a health professional, you are the lifeline of the community. Give full attention to every client and follow protocol during every community visit.

pages.text: What will you do with the torn net?

dialogues.text: Let's sew up the torn portions of the net
Yes, that sounds wonderful. Let me get a needle and thread.

info_start: Hello Nurse!
Let's help Ama with her net.
An Insectide Treated Net has four corners to hang.
Hit the Power Gauge dead center 4 TIMES to hang the net.
Miss any corner and you're going to have to try again
Let's GO!
info_end: You've help Ama hang her Insectide Treated Net properly.
info_skip: You will lose some points for this
info_replay: Oh No!
You didn't get all the corners of the net hanged properly.
Let's Try Harder!

dialogues.text: Let's tie up the torn portions of the net
Yes, that sounds wonderful. Let me get some thread or rope.

text:
Unacceptable!
 Malaria prevention requires the utmost diligence. Tying the net may be a quick workaround but that's not going to fix the issue adequately. 
There are better options available.

dialogues.text: Let's hang up the torn net
Whatever you say Aunty Nurse.

text:
Really? 
Malaria prevention requires the utmost diligence. 
You totally ignored the tear in the net. Mosquitoes will find a way into the net, bite the client, possibly leading to malaria.

dialogues.text: Thank you so much, Nurse Adwoa
You're welcome.
Ama, were you given any medication at the ANC clinic?
Yes. They gave me three white pills and I took it in front of the midwife
Yes. SP treatment. Remember to keep your next appointment too. Thank you for letting me into your home
Thank you, Nurse Adwoa
Thank you for letting me into your home. See you next time
Thank you, Nurse Adwoa

text: Hold On! You're not out to set a new record in fastest community visits.
There are other Malaria in pregnancy issues left undiscussed with the client.  Pregnant women need strict and diligent Malaria prevention and care.

dialogues.text: Now to Madam Kyeiwaa's compound...
Good afternoon.
Good afternoon.
Welcome. I'm almost done here.
Thank you Kwesi.

text:
Oh No!

CBAs/Volunteers are depending on you.

As the supervising health personnel within the community, knowing the most vital questions to ask to get information for diagnosis, is critical. Wrong questions, result in wrong answers.

TRY AGAIN!

info_start: You've just seen a CBA treating a child within the community.
Think carefully and decide what three questions you will ask him?
Let's GO!
info_end: You're on top of things as a supervisor.
info_skip: You will lose some points for this
info_replay: Oh No!
As the supervising health personnel within the community, CBAs/Volunteers are depending on you.
Knowing the most vital questions to ask is critical for diagnosis.
Wrong questions, result in wrong answers.
TRY AGAIN!

dialogues.text: Kwesi, what process did you follow before administering Artesunate-Amodiaquine?
I followed the guidelines. The mother said the child has been feeling cold, shivering, headache, generally unwell.
I suspected malaria, so I used an RDT test kit, to try and confirm my diagnosis.
It was positive, so I sanitized my hand and started the first dosage.
Was I right?
Let me see the RDT result?
Excellent. You followed the guidelines well. It's uncomplicated malaria and he should be fine
Seems, you've run out of proper disposal bags. Let me help you.

text:
Hey, Adwoa, Kwesi needs help disposing of the RDT Cassette properly. Can you help him?

Let's get out the Paper Storage Bag.

dialogues.text: Thanks, Nurse Adwoa
One question. Can you help me revise the process for severe malaria?

info_start: Kwesi, one of the CBA's within your community,
wants to confirm the process of diagnosing severe malaria. Let's help him
1. We've used Six (6) steps to describe the correct sequence of actions for diagnosing severe malaria
2. Pick the five (6) right actions from the list on your left.
3. Arrange them in the correct sequence on the right.
Let's GO!
info_end: You've Helped Youself out big time.
info_skip: You will lose some points for this
info_replay: It really is complicated for you.
You know how to diagnose uncomplicated malaria but differentiating it from severe malaria, not so much.
Severe malaria is life threatening and failing to diagnose this can lead to very bad results for your patients.
TRY AGAIN!

text:
Sorry!

  Differentiating between uncomplicated and severe malaria is vital. 
Severe malaria is life threatening and must be diagnosed quickly and correctly to save lives. There are several key differences in signs and symptoms you must know.

dialogues.text: No. You missed it. It's not uncomplicated malaria at all
No. You missed it. It's not uncomplicated malaria at all

text: No, that is not the correct interpretation!

Pay careful attention to results depicted on the cassette of any test you perform. Results may seem similar but an error will cause harm to clients especially vulnerable ones like children under five and pregnant women.

LET'S HAVE ANOTHER TRY!

dialogues.text: Yes. It's just as I expected. Thank you so much for confirming this info
It's my job to help and I am glad to do it.
Before I leave, I almost forgot

info_start: You've almost completed your supervising visit with Kwesi. However, there are a list of activities you should complete first.
1. There are 8 activities on the left including some important activities for community health supervisors.
2. Drag each correct option to an empty slot on the right. How many are correct options are there you ask? That's up to you!
3. Choose Wisely. Let's Go!
info_end: You're almost done with your community health mission.
info_skip: You will lose some points for this
info_replay: Nope!
You did not get it right.
Let's Try Again!

text: Wait! Your visit is not done!
Your supervision is vital to ensuring that CBAs/Volunteers are performing their duties correctly. Knowing what duties they are to perform is the first step in providing adequate supervision.
YES! You are ready to progress to the next level. As a nurse you know what that means right? It's time for an EXAM.
There are 10 Questions. You need to score at least 80% (8/10) to proceed.
Pass this and you will have earned the right to the next Grade as a Nurse.
GOOD LUCK!
Oh No! You didn't get the pass mark required.

Let's give it another try and this time, let's get it right

TRY AGAIN!

pages.text:
Congrats, You have completed this chapter of Hello Nurse.
To be Continued
